All travellers must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.
They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:
Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
Negative test (within 72 hours).
In addition:
• There is no requirement to self-isolate on arrival.
• Travellers who are not vaccinated or recovered, and who arrive by their own transport from countries other than EU/Schengen Area states, Switzerland, UK, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican, without a negative pre-departure test must take one and pay for it when they arrive.
• All travellers are recommended to take the PCR or antigen test within 3 days of arrival.

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU: [as below]

*Transit:

Transit is allowed for citizens of non-EU/Schengen area countries:

  • On their return to their country of residence;
  • In whose respect a reasoned request has been made by a foreign country;
  • Via the territory of the Russian Federation to Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation and backward (via Kena railway border checkpoint and Kybartai railway border checkpoint).

Citizens of Ukraine: Ukrainian travellers arriving from Poland or other EU countries do not have to provide test results and there is no requirement for them to quarantine.



*From Third Countries:

Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) within 270 days (the 270-day rule does not apply to children under age 18 years), or those who have a booster dose, or those who qualify for special exemptions. From 15 February, entry is allowed for citizens of select countries.

Travellers are required to provide one of the following documents:

1. Proof of vaccination. Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Covishield and Nuvaxovid. For adults over age 18, the primary vaccination certificate is valid for 270 days (it is unlimited for children under age 18 and also for adults with a booster shot).

Or

2. Certificate of recovery valid for 180 days.

Or

3. Negative test result: PCR test (maximum 72 hours).

The following rules also apply:

  • There is no requirement to self-isolate on arrival.
  • Travellers who are not vaccinated or recovered, and who arrive by their own transport from countries other than EU/Schengen Area states, Switzerland, UK, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican, without a negative pre-departure test must take one and pay for it when they arrive.
  • All travellers are recommended to take the PCR or antigen test within 3 days of arrival.

Citizens of Ukraine: Ukrainian travellers arriving from Poland and other EU countries do not have to provide test results and there is no requirement to quarantine.

Internal Restrictions:
*Facemasks: You are required to wear a medical facemask on public transport and in medical facilities. These rules do not apply to children under the age of six, or people with a medical exemption. If you cannot wear facemasks on medical grounds, you are advised to wear face shields if possible.
The Lithuanian Government advise that you continue wearing facemasks in indoor spaces with poor ventilation, large groups of people, or where it is not possible to maintain a safe distance from other people.
Public places and services: The Lithuanian Government no long requires individuals to prove their vaccination status in order to access non-essential services.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
